data.content: The Liberals are dropping a plan to add hundreds of firearms to a list of banned weapons in Canada as part of their broader promise to tighten gun laws in Canada. data.content: The definition is expected to be part of a new package of amendments that could land within days as the legislative clock on the federal government’s latest effort to tighten gun laws — Bill C-21 — is running out.

data.content: At this time last year, Toronto recorded 66 shootings, out of which 13 were fatal. In 2023, so far, there have been 19 shootings — and none has been fatal. According to Louis March, founder of the Zero Gun Violence Movement, the decline can be attributed to strong government control and the disruption of illegal guns coming in from across the border.

data.title: Canada Border Services Agency arrests a man for smuggling firearms
data.content: Recently, the Canada Border Services Agency lay charges in a firearm investigation and arrested a 30-year-old man for smuggling firearms. This was a part of the efforts to disrupt the flow of illegal guns coming in from across the border.

data.title: Bill C-21 bans 1,500 models and variants of firearms
data.content: In 2022, the Liberal government's Bill C-21 banned some 1,500 models and variants of firearms, including the AR-15 and Ruger Mini-14 on the grounds that they have no place in hunting or sports. Moreover, Trudeau announced that the government is looking at a 'variety of options' to carry out a buyback of banned firearms after the government estimated that there are approximately 150,000 registered firearms in Canada that would be bought back.

data.title: Poverty contributes to gun violence in Canada
data.content: Most of the gun violence, or criminal activity, is mostly in neighbourhoods where poverty is one of the biggest challenges. People can get involved in criminal activity because they don't see an alternative, especially in populations that are 'stigmatized, denied access, denied opportunity, denied education, or denied employment.' According to Jackie Sultana Sikdar, a second-year PhD student at York University, there are too many obstacles and limitations in terms of cultural, social, and economic spheres that contribute to crime — including gun violence.

data.title: Community organizations can help reduce gun violence in Canada
data.content: According to March and Sikdar, more mobilization in the community combined with policing and government policies can work together like pieces of a 'jigsaw puzzle' to reduce gun violence in cities. Nonprofit organizations are fostering strong social networks, empowering people to work together, and keeping their own community safe. These organizations are influencing the needed systemic changes.
